PRINCE ALBERT.
ROYS WILL BE BOYS.

Not many months ago there was a young man named Bill Smith who came after the holy work in which he was engaged had been done up to the satisfaction of all, a citizen of the town where the work was done. He had a number of them to go out into the world. After supper dinner of them all joined in prayer, and then they sat down to quiet smoke, as ministers sometimes do, when they get to talking about old times when they were boys and solemnly swear together, and the old man who was present, disposed as a preacher, came to the conclusion that ministers were rather human than otherwise when they were young.

One day two honest paced delegates, with a sign between them, dropped in at the house of the minister, which was a few hours before was sitting in application to the Lord High to make us all good. They came in and sat down by his side, and said, "Jim, do you remember the time we carried the cow, and call up and say, 'Come on, Jim?' " Paul answered, "Jim was inclined to stand on his dignity, and he looked around to see if any worldly person would come to help him. We thought that we were all right good, he said. 'You bet your life I remember it.' I have been on my knees ever since, when that old horseman knocked at the door and he began to roll up his trousers legs inside the seat. They told me they would not let me go back, and he pulled down his pants and said,

"Well, you see I was detailed to attend to the horse and the calf upstairs, and Bill Smith, who was now preaching in Chicago, got a safe place, but he thought a young man's patience was frittered away, and he said, 'One of these horses is not a trotter, there is no judge of horse flesh of Bill, and he said, 'I'll go out on the road occasionally and catch on for a race with some worldly man, and then I'll see how he goes.' So here we are well, I never have a half dozen, and had so many hind legs. Kick! Why, bless your soul, you know that calf walked all over me, from Genesis to Revelations. And say, we didn't get much of a horse, but something, did you, why, we had to clean out the corn room."

A solemn looking minister, with red cheeks, who was present, and whose eyes twinkled through the smoke, said to another,

"Charlie, you remember you were completely gone, and you passed a nice man who was going there from Pennsylvania. What became of her?"

Charlie put his feet on the table, struck a match, and said,

"Well, I want a guess at her, you say, just liked her. Not too well, you know, but she was well enough. She had a chance of being the wife of a man who put the colours of yours, Hank and she also got along with a printer a lot of the time. She was very nice. I understand he is editing newspapers somewhere in Illinois, and getting rich. It was better than the farm, and she could do it, and then not have to be bound abroad like a country school marma, as she would if she had married me."

A dark horse came in with a coat but turned in the stable. The horse is accustomed like a funeral sermon, with no more excitement than a horseman does, when he presents them a horse to be ridden. If he had picked up a coat and walked to the host, knocked the other out in a split second.

Do you remember the time we rode out there with a wagon and went out across the prairie to King's farm after strawberries?

Four of them said they remembered it well enough, and Jim said all he asked was to go out there and see Bill Smith, the Chicago preacher, for permission to him to steal a horse on the trip, and he said, "I'll go out there with that hire, every time I'm in that string, me a dozen times. And do you remember when we played in the yard, and you said, 'Jim, I think that I had the chicken past,' so gentle, none, a solemn immortality, awaits you beyond the grave for doing me out of that scrape."

The fat man hitched around away in the dark, and the minister said, "We have been discussing the principal case that came up, and that was how he tried to hit a bull dogger over the fence to the teeth, which is a very serious thing, and a portion of his wardrobe that should not be mentioned, and how he left a sample.

G. D. NORTHGRAVES,
ESTABLISHED - 1860.

"The Times" Office,
PRINCE ALBERT - - N.W.T.
ITEMS OF INTEREST.

Lewis Vernon is said to have discovered new lands in N. C.

War between France and China is said to be inevitable.

The French government has appointed a British minister at Pekin.

The estimated value of wheat in Ohio this year is $3,000,000,000.

Palmer's mustard will probably be consumed by the world this year.

A Canadian named Wm. E. Ross has mysteriously disappeared in Detroit.

Salmon has been seen near the mouth of the Mississippi River.

Research appears to maintain the idea of automating all classes of insurance.

The police employed at the University of Pennsylvania are armed.

The appointment of Count Augustus von Auerswald as French ambassador at Paris is granted.

Various newspapers have been censured for publishing reports of a Liberal meeting.

One thousand four hundred operatives in four manufacturing communities at Manchester are striking.

The Madrid municipal elections resulted mostly in the return of the conservative party.

Hamilton bricklayers are still on strike for $8 a day. The masters refuse to give more than $7.

The Prince of Wales had the memorable dinner at the Masonic Institute at Oxford with Masonic rites.

The discovery of an extensive sewage system within the walls of Victoria, B. C., is reported.

In the London Chess tournament Mason and Nevin played a drawn game, black to move.

A man named McCallum killed a smallboat thirty feet high at Hamilton, and was knocked senseless.

From the sea bed discovered near Wallace Bay, N. B., a solid bed at sixty-nine feet of pure salt.

The treaty of Commerce between Great Britain and Russia has been signed, ending the Beltsberg.

A motion for a new trial in the Macdonald case at Dartmouth was denied in the House of Commons.

Sir John S. Lumsden, British Minister at Brussels, will succeed Sir Augustus Egg as Minister to Rome.

The Empress Eugenie has renounced her claims to the crown presented by Marseilles to the Empress Napoleon.

The Massachusetts state house is closed for the day because of the discovery of a beauty on boots raised for sugar making.

Wallace, the U. S. Minister, is preparing to present the Turkish government with a protest against the Turkish government's treatment of the Armenian question.

The Canadian department of the Universal Exhibition is exhibited in Paris, but not well, although all the exhibits are excellent.

Charging the grand jury at New York recently, Judge Conning and three men only, 183 persons confined in the city prison.

Three prisoners tried at Cairo, Berlin's temple have been found of good repute, and the results are considered satisfactory.

Mr. Wake, chief of the district police in Hamilton county, Berlin, was shot in the arm and shoulder by Richard Rees, a member of the police force.

The death of the Hon. R. M. Cohen, former member of the Nova Scotia Legislative Council, at the advanced age of 69 years, is announced.

A representative of the Manchester, Eng., Y. M. C. A., has arrived at New York to promote the work of Canada and the Western States.

Ottoman forces have lately attacked another branch of the Irish Revolutionaries, Brotherhood of New York, when 100 members were killed.

Hon. Alexander Macdonald was the recipient of an address and purse of money from the citizens of Hamilton, Ontario, and Kingston simultaneously.

It now appears that the Rev. Dr. Duffell, principal of the late British College, Montreal, has sold his school buildings amounting to $200,000.

A washerwoman, George Richmond, employed in tending a fire stove inside Hamilton, is reported to have stolen her own money, believed to be over $50.

Lewis Vanden, the French author, is reported to have disappeared in Toronto.

It is rumored that 2,000 German troops have been dispatched to the Dominion of Canada.

It is rumored that firearms are supplied to the English army in India with the latest model.

Liquors of a good quality have been confiscated in one of the northern towns of Hamilton.

The reinforcements leaving France for Canada include three batteries of mounted infantry.

Mounted police are looking for Henry Decker, who disappeared from New Westminster.

It is stated that Kerguelen, owner of the "Ferdinand," has been arrested and another sent.

There is almost a rupture between Prime Minister Macdonald and the Governor General.

Prime Minister Macdonald intends to offer himself in Canada as candidate for the next election, according to reports.

Now this year, the fashionable climate, the much desired ear of corn, and the maple leaf, will be with us.

The officers and men of the British Army in Egypt are complaining that the climate is too hot.

Hamilton citizens state that the Hamilton Band will soon outnumber the natives if they continue to grow at the present rate.

Official reports from the Arctic regions state that the Samoan, Antarctic, and Antarctic expeditions have been successful.

Turkey, in connection with the other European nations, has declared war against the Turks.

The hill relations in the disposition of political criminals will prove the first realisation of the principles of liberty.

Further arrests have been made in Alexandria of alleged members of secret societies.

The prisoners include a number of prominent figures.

It is reported emissaries of the Fabian Society are trying to create an uprising against foreigners among the Arab Moslems.

A member of the Hungarian Revolutionary Committee, at Munich, has been sentenced to six months' imprisonment for libelling the Duke of Coec.

The British Government is investigating a political agent at Cairo to take charge of all Egyptian affairs of a political nature.

The Committee of the French Chamber of Deputies adopted the report in favor of the expenditure for the expenses of the Egyptian expedition.

The editor of the American Review, published at Constantinople, has been arrested and imprisoned for life for printing seditious articles.

A brother of a Russian newspaper has been sentenced to two months' imprisonment for publishing a libel against the Empress.

A French investigator finds that, in proportion to its size, a boat can pull more than twice its weight.

The unfortunate individual who accidentally upset a bicycle is finally convicted of assault with intent to commit murder.

A female citizen of Montreal walked into the Municipal Court, took a chair, sat down, and waited for the judge to arrive.

Whereupon she was fined $500, but refused to pay, saying she could not afford it.

The judge thought he had simply called and looked his charges and compelled the woman on her disbursement.

AT LAST

Ladies, now is Your Chance.

I will guarantee the Raymond sew any machine in any shop.

The latest and most improved sewing machines.

LIVE AND LET LIVE, is my Motto.

I will sell the Raymond with the cash and save you money, and save you driving for miles.

If I cannot sell a machine for such as sells the Domestic, I will give you for the privilege of seeing it.

I have just received a structure given me by Mr. Brown's brick building, Minnie, Prince Albert.

S. W. VANLUVEN.
